articles.headline: Health Care Law Projected to Cut the Labor Force
articles.snippet: With the expansion of insurance coverage, more workers will choose not to work and others will choose to work fewer hours than they might have otherwise, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
articles.abstract: With the expansion of insurance coverage, more workers will choose not to work and others will choose to work fewer hours than they might have otherwise, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Congressional Budget Office analysis released Tuesday predicted that the Affordable Care Act would shrink the work force by the equivalent of more than two million full-time positions and recharged the political debate over the health care law, providing Republican opponents fresh lines of attack and putting Democrats on the defensive.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Target Vows to Speed Anti-Fraud Technology
articles.snippet: John Mulligan, Target’s chief executive, testified at a Senate hearing on EMV, a European-based technology that embeds a small chip instead of a magnetic stripe on credit cards.
articles.abstract: John Mulligan, Target’s chief executive, testified at a Senate hearing on EMV, a European-based technology that embeds a small chip instead of a magnetic stripe on credit cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top executive of Target told a Senate committee on Tuesday that the company was accelerating plans to adopt a technology widely used in Europe but rare in the United States that reduces potential for credit card fraud, and lawmakers from both parties called on other businesses to do the same.

articles.headline: S.&P. Lowers Puerto Rico Debt to Junk Status
articles.snippet: The move intensified a cash squeeze for the commonwealth, whose financial condition is of outsize importance to the rest of the United States because its debt is widely held by individual investors through mutual funds.
articles.abstract: The move intensified a cash squeeze for the commonwealth, whose financial condition is of outsize importance to the rest of the United States because its debt is widely held by individual investors through mutual funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | Standard & Poor’s downgraded the debt of Puerto Rico to junk status on Tuesday, intensifying a cash squeeze for the commonwealth, whose financial condition is of outsize importance to the rest of the United States because its debt is widely held by individual investors through mutual funds.

articles.headline: Health Law Goals Face Antitrust Hurdles
articles.snippet: A judge in Idaho ruled against a hospital deal, saying that patient costs would have risen, but that outcomes would have been improved.
articles.abstract: A judge in Idaho ruled against a hospital deal, saying that patient costs would have risen, but that outcomes would have been improved.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the midterm elections fast coming into focus, politics in Washington will remain consumed by health care for months to come.

articles.headline: Welcome Relief for Homeowners, Until the Tax Bill Arrives
articles.snippet: JPMorgan can write off $1.5 billion in debt relief, but it will be treated as taxable income for homeowners, resulting in burdensome costs for many families.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan can write off $1.5 billion in debt relief, but it will be treated as taxable income for homeowners, resulting in burdensome costs for many families.
articles.lead_paragraph: Come tax time, JPMorgan Chase will be able to write off the $1.5 billion in debt relief it must give homeowners to satisfy the terms of a recent settlement.

articles.headline: WellPoint, a Onetime Critic of Health Law, May Yet Profit
articles.snippet: The giant insurer outraged customers by proposing a 40 percent rise in some premiums a few years ago. Nowadays, it has emerged as the biggest participant in state marketplaces.
articles.abstract: The giant insurer outraged customers by proposing a 40 percent rise in some premiums a few years ago. Nowadays, it has emerged as the biggest participant in state marketplaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — In the midst of the sweeping transformation taking place in health insurance, the company that served as an illustration of why an overhaul was necessary could end up benefiting most from the new federal health care law.

articles.headline: In Texting Era, Crisis Hotlines Put Help at Youths’ Fingertips
articles.snippet: Texting has become such a fundamental way to communicate that crisis groups have begun to adopt it as an alternative way of providing emergency services and counseling.
articles.abstract: Texting has become such a fundamental way to communicate that crisis groups have begun to adopt it as an alternative way of providing emergency services and counseling.
articles.lead_paragraph: The conversation began abruptly, with the anonymous teenager getting straight to the point: She had just told her family that she was really a boy trapped in a female body. “Now my family hates me,” she told a crisis counselor.

articles.headline: New Boss at Microsoft, With Gates at His Side
articles.snippet: Bill Gates, who co-founded Microsoft but has spent his time on other pursuits, will return part-time to the company after the new chief executive, Satya Nadella, asked him to be his adviser.
articles.abstract: Bill Gates, who co-founded Microsoft but has spent his time on other pursuits, will return part-time to the company after the new chief executive, Satya Nadella, asked him to be his adviser.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Bill Gates is back in the building at Microsoft.

articles.headline: An Olympics in the Shadow of a War Zone
articles.snippet: The symbolic importance of the Games for Russia has turned Sochi into a target for Islamic terrorists who have vowed a wave of attacks to advance their goal of an independent caliphate across the North Caucasus.
articles.abstract: The symbolic importance of the Games for Russia has turned Sochi into a target for Islamic terrorists who have vowed a wave of attacks to advance their goal of an independent caliphate across the North Caucasus.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKSAN, Russia — On Friday, exactly a week before the Olympics were set to open just 180 miles away, Russia’s security forces appeared on Makhov Street at 8:30 a.m. and cordoned off the area around a brick and stone house. One of the men inside called his father, who said it was the first he had heard from his son in 10 months.

articles.headline: Google Settles Its European Antitrust Case; Critics Remain
articles.snippet: If approved, the deal would put an end to half a decade of wrangles with antitrust authorities across the globe.
articles.abstract: If approved, the deal would put an end to half a decade of wrangles with antitrust authorities across the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google has agreed to a settlement with European competition regulators that leaves the company with a few bruises, yet victorious over all — and would end half a decade of wrangles with antitrust authorities across the globe.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Mark Scott

articles.headline: CVS Vows to Quit Selling Tobacco Products
articles.snippet: The drugstore chain sees itself as a health care provider and says the sale of cigarettes doesn’t fit that image, even though the company stands to lose $2 billion in sales.
articles.abstract: The drugstore chain sees itself as a health care provider and says the sale of cigarettes doesn’t fit that image, even though the company stands to lose $2 billion in sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: CVS Caremark, the country’s largest drugstore chain in overall sales, announced on Wednesday that it planned to stop selling cigarettes and other tobacco products by October.
